body:
1. Return result as simple text entry to War Room
    demisto.results("Mission Accomplished")
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "1". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes['note'],
        'Contents': data,
        'ContentsFormat' : formats['json'],
        'HumanReadable': md,
        'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats['markdown'],
        'EntryContext' : context}

  3. Return data to the war room as a file
    demisto.results(fileResult('filename',data))
  4. Return an error to War Room
    myErrorText  = "No matching sensors."
    demisto.results( { "Type" : entryTypes["error"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : myErrorText } )
  5. Return multiple entries to War Room
    output = []
    output.append( { "Type" : entryTypes["error"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : "First part of the script failed." } )
    output += [ { "Type" : entryTypes["note"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : "Second part of the script completed successfully." } ]
    demisto.results( output )
  6. Get context value
    Fetches the value from the context by it's key. demisto.get(demisto.context(), 'key')
  7. Set Context
    To set context from an integration, you can inject context through the returned entry. In this example an entry result is sent to the War Room that adds the key.subkey to the current incident context. 
    demisto.results( { "Type" : entryTypes["note"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : "data", "EntryContext": { "key.subkey": "value" } } )
  8. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    demisto.setContext('myIPs', ['1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2']);

    demisto.setContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  9. Format Results as a table
    In addition to plain text, you can return results to the war room formatted as a table. Error entries can also be formatted as tables, by setting the `entryType`to `error`.

    res = [ {"col1" : "val1", "col2" : 1} ]

    res.append( {"col1" : "val2", "col2" : 2} )

    demisto.results( {'ContentsFormat': formats['table'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res} )
  10. Format Results using Markdown
    Results can also be formatted using Markdown.

    if entry['Type'] != entryTypes['error'] and entry['ContentsFormat'] == formats['json']:

        res += '\n### Users:'

        res += '\n- High Risk: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.highRisk'))

        res += '\n- Recent: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.recent'))

        res += '\n- Total: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.total'))

    demisto.results({'ContentsFormat': formats['markdown'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res})
  11. Set Results As Notes
    Results can be tagged as Notes

    res = '## This is a note\n'

    res += 'It has important information\n'

    demisto.results({'ContentsFormat': formats['markdown'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res, 'Note': True})
  12. Access Investigation Metadata
    1. When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your scriptâ€™s logic and purpose.

     To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

     demisto.results( demisto.investigation() )

     To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

     demisto.results( demisto.incidents() )

  13. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: demisto.log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: demisto.info(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: demisto.debug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: demisto.error(...)

  14. Incident Severity Levels
    • Unknown: 0
    • Informational: .5
    • Low: 1
    • Medium: 2
    • High: 3
    • Critical: 4
  15. Incident Statuses
    • Pending: 0
    • Active: 1
    • Done: 2
    • Archive: 3

1. Return result as simple text entry to War Room
    return "Mission Accomplished";
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "1". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes.note,
        'Contents': data,
        'ContentsFormat' : formats.json,
        'HumanReadable': md,
        'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats.markdown,
        'EntryContext' : context}

  3. Return data to the war room as a file
    return saveFile(res.Body);
  4. Return an error to War Room
    return { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.error, Contents: 'First part of the script failed.' };
  5. Return multiple entries to War Room
    var output = [];
    output.push( { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.error, Contents: 'First part of the script failed.' } );
    output.push( { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: 'Second part of the script completed successfully.' } );
    return output;
  6. Get Context value
    Fetches the value from the context by it's key. dq(invContext,'key.path')
  7. Set Context
    setContext(args.key, args.value);
  8. Sending an HTTP request or file
    http(url,{Method: method,Headers: headers,Body: body, Username: username,Password: password},params.insecure,params.proxy);
    httpMultipart(url,file_id,{Headers: headers, Username: username,Password: password},body,params.insecure,params.proxy,false,'uploadFile', file_name,true);
    http sends a request and receives a response and httpMultipart sends a file in HTTP protocol
    where:
    URL: the site url (mandatory)
    method is the http method such as 'GET', 'POST', 'PUT' (mandatory)
    fileID is the entry ID of the file in the War room
    headers is the HTTP request headers
    body is the http request body
    username and password are the authentication details if needed
    insecure is a Boolean parameter that is true if secure and false if not secure.
    proxy is a Boolean parameter that is true to use proxy and false if not use proxy.
    file_name is the name of the file that is sent. Can be different than the file ID.;
  9. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    setContext('myIPs', ['1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2']);

    setContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  10. Format Results as a table
    In addition to plain text, you can return results to the war room formatted as a table. Error entries can also be formatted as tables, by setting the `entryType` to `error`.

    rows = [ { col1 : 'val1', col2 : 1 } , { col1 : 'val2', col2 : 2 } ]

    return {ContentsFormat: formats.table, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: rows};

  11. Format Results using Markdown

    Results can also be formatted using Markdown.

    var res = '## My title\n### My subsection\n'

    rows = [ { col1 : 'val1', col2 : 1 } , { col1 : 'val2', col2 : 2 } ]

    markdownBasedTable = 'num|col1|col2\n'

    markdownBasedTable += '---|---|---\n'

    for (var i = 0; i < rows.length; i++)

    markdownBasedTable += (i+1) + '|' + rows[i].col1 + '|' + rows[i].col2 + '\n'

    res += markdownBasedTable

    return { ContentsFormat: formats.markdown, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: res } ;
  12. Set Results As Notes

    Results can be set as notes

    var res = '## This is a note\n';

    res += 'It has important information\n';

    return { ContentsFormat: formats.markdown, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: res, Note: true } ;
  13. Base 64

    btoa: encode string to base 64

    atob: decode base 64 to string

    entrytoa: gets a file entry ID and returns the file in base 64.

  14. Access Investigation Metadata

    When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your script's logic and purpose.

    To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

    return investigation;

    To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

    return incidents;

  15. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: logInfo(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: logDebug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: logError(...)

  16. Incident Severity Levels
    • Unknown: 0
    • Informational: .5
    • Low: 1
    • Medium: 2
    • High: 3
    • Critical: 4
  17. Incident Statuses
    • Pending: 0
    • Active: 1
    • Done: 2
    • Archive: 3

1. Return result as simple text entry to the War Room
    $demisto.Results("Mission Accomplished")
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "note". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Field: Tags 
    Expected Values: List of strings 
    Description: Tags to apply to the War Room entry.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes.note,
    'Contents': data,
    'ContentsFormat' : formats.json,
    'HumanReadable': md,
    'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats.markdown,
    'EntryContext' : context,
    'Tags' : @('tag1', 'tag2')}

  3. Return an error to War Room
    myErrorText  = "No matching sensors."
    $demisto.Results( @{ Type = 1; ContentsFormat = "json"; Contents = $contents; EntryContext = $context; ReadableContentsFormat = "markdown"; HumanReadable = $contents } )
  4. Set Context
    $demisto.SetContext(demisto.Args().key, demisto.Args().'value')
  5. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    $demisto.SetContext('myIPs', '1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2');

    $demisto.SetContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  6. Access Investigation Metadata
    1. When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your script�s logic and purpose.

     To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

     $demisto.Results( demisto.Investigation() )

     To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

     $demisto.Results( demisto.Incidents() )

  7. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: $demisto.Log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: $demisto.Info(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: $demisto.Debug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: $demisto.Error(...)

  8. Close the current investigation
    $demisto.ExecuteCommand('closeInvestigation', @{ reason_What-happened : 'Automated malware playbook completed.' } )
  9. Advanced How To
    To be added soon:
    1. Access War Room entries from within a script - return entries matching a specific condition, aggregate content from entries, run a regex-based search against all text in the war room to collect a list of identifiers, and more.
    2. Send files from war room as email attachments.
    3. Access context data directly disregarding arguments.
    4.More tips and use cases to come.
  10. Incident Severity Levels
    • Unknown: 0
    • Informational: .5
    • Low: 1
    • Medium: 2
    • High: 3
    • Critical: 4
  11. Incident Statuses
    • Pending: 0
    • Active: 1
    • Done: 2
    • Archive: 3

1. Return result as simple text entry to the War Room
    demisto.results("Mission Accomplished")
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "note". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Field: Tags 
    Expected Values: List of strings 
    Description: Tags to apply to the War Room entry.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes['note'],
    'Contents': data,
    'ContentsFormat' : formats['json'],
    'HumanReadable': md,
    'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats['markdown'],
    'EntryContext' : context,
    'Tags' : ['tag1', 'tag2']}

  3. Return data to the War Room as a file
    demisto.results(fileResult('filename',data))
  4. Return an error to War Room
    myErrorText  = "No matching sensors."
    demisto.results( { "Type" : entryTypes["error"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : myErrorText } )
  5. Return multiple entries to War Room
    output = []
    output.append( { "Type" : entryTypes["error"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : "First part of the script failed." } )
    output += [ { "Type" : entryTypes["note"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : "Second part of the script completed successfully." } ]
    demisto.results( output )
  6. Getting time and other metadata for war room entries
    e = demisto.executeCommand('getEntry', {'id': '270@4dfc3b65-9da2-46c5-8751-ebe959f31a7b'}); demisto.results(demisto.get(e[0], 'Metadata.Created'));
  7. Getting metadata for war room entries in JSON
    e = demisto.executeCommand('getEntry', {'id': '60@4751'}); demisto.results(json.dumps(e[0]['Metadata'], indent=2));
  8. Execute Commands
    arrResultEntries = demisto.executeCommand('ip', { "ip" : "8.8.8.8" } )
  9. Get context value
    Fetches the value from the context by it's key. demisto.get(demisto.context(), 'key')
  10. Set Context
    demisto.setContext(demisto.args()['key'], demisto.args()['value'])
  11. Set an Incident
    demisto.executeCommand("setIncident", {'mydate': '2018-02-02T22:58:21+02:00'})
  12. Send notifications (e.g. Email)
    demisto.executeCommand("send-mail", { "to" : "user@domain.com", "cc" : "also@domain.com", "subject" : "Update on Demisto investigation", "body" : "Contents of your message." } )
  13. Handle Errors
    1. output = []

    resultEntries = demisto.executeCommand( 'dummy-command', { 'arg' : 'value' } )

    try:

        if isError( resultEntries[0] ):

            # We have something special to say about this error

    if 'failed with status 404 NOT FOUND' in resultEntries[0]['Contents']:

    demisto.results( { 'Type' : entryTypes['error'], 'ContentsFormat' : formats['text'], 'Contents' : 'Received HTTP Error 404 from Session API. Please ensure that you do not already have an active session with that sensor, and if not - report to the sysadmin.' } )

            else:

    # If it's not the error we recognize - send all entries returned from the command back to the war room as-is

                demisto.results(resultEntries)

        else:

    demisto.results( { 'Type' : entryTypes['note'], 'ContentsFormat' : formats['text'], 'Contents': 'Success.' } )

    except Exception as ex:

    demisto.results( { 'Type' : entryTypes['error'], 'Contentmat' : formats['text'], 'Contents' : 'Error occurred while parsing output from command. Exception info:\n' + str(ex) + '\n\nInvalid output:\n' + str( resultEntries ) } )
  14. Execute Another Script
    You can execute other scripts just as you execute commands, using `executeCommand`.

    arrResultEntries = demisto.executeCommand( "IPReputation", { "ip" : "8.8.8.8" } )

  15. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    demisto.setContext('myIPs', ['1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2']);

    demisto.setContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  16. Reading file contents
    demisto.executeCommand('getFilePath', {'id': demisto.args()['entryId'] })

    filePath = resultEntries[0]["Contents"]["path"] with open(filePath , 'rb') as file:

    data = file.read()

    demisto.log('Actual file path on disk was: ' + filePath)

    demisto.results( { "Type" : entryTypes["note"], "ContentsFormat" : formats["text"], "Contents" : data } )

  17. Format Results as a table
    In addition to plain text, you can return results to the war room formatted as a table. Error entries can also be formatted as tables, by setting the `entryType` to `error`.

    res = [ {"col1" : "val1", "col2" : 1} ]

    res.append( {"col1" : "val2", "col2" : 2} )

    demisto.results( {'ContentsFormat': formats['table'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res} )
  18. Format Results using Markdown
    Results can also be formatted using Markdown.

    res = '## Exabeam global info'

    entry = demisto.executeCommand('xb-users', {})[0]

    if entry['Type'] != entryTypes['error'] and entry['ContentsFormat'] == formats['json']:

        res += '\n### Users:'

    res += '\n- High Risk: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.highRisk'))

    res += '\n- Recent: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.recent'))

    res += '\n- Total: ' + str(demisto.get(entry, 'Contents.total'))

    demisto.results({'ContentsFormat': formats['markdown'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res})
  19. Set Results As Notes
    Results can be tagged as Notes

    res = '## This is a note\n'

    res += 'It has important information\n'

    demisto.results({'ContentsFormat': formats['markdown'], 'Type': entryTypes['note'], 'Contents': res, 'Note': True})
  20. Access Investigation Metadata
    1. When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your scriptâ€™s logic and purpose.

     To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

     demisto.results( demisto.investigation() )

     To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

     demisto.results( demisto.incidents() )

  21. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: demisto.log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: demisto.info(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: demisto.debug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: demisto.error(...)

  22. Close the current investigation
    demisto.executeCommand('closeInvestigation', { 'reason_What-happened' : 'Automated malware playbook completed.' } )
  23. Advanced How To
    To be added soon:
    1. Access War Room entries from within a script â€“ return entries matching a specific condition, aggregate content from entries, run a regex-based search against all text in the war room to collect a list of identifiers, and more.
    2. Send files from war room as email attachments.
    3. Access context data directly disregarding arguments.
    4.More tips and use cases to come.
  24. Return a map to the War Room
    demisto.results({
    'Type': entryTypes['map'],
    'ContentsFormat' : formats['json'],
    'Contents': {
    'lat': <latitude-coordinate>,
    'lng': <longitude-coordinate>,
    }
  25. Incident Severity Levels
    • Unknown: 0
    • Informational: .5
    • Low: 1
    • Medium: 2
    • High: 3
    • Critical: 4
  26. Incident Statuses

    • Active: 1

1. Return result as simple text entry to the War Room
    return "Mission Accomplished";
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "note". Example: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "note". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Field: Tags 
    Expected Values: List of strings 
    Description: Tags to apply to the War Room entry.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes.note,
    'Contents': data,
    'ContentsFormat' : formats.json,
    'HumanReadable': md,
    'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats.markdown,
    'EntryContext' : context,
    'Tags' : ['tag1', 'tag2']}

  3. Return data to the War Room as a file
    return saveFile(res.Body);
  4. Return an error to the War Room
    return { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.error, Contents: 'First part of the script failed.' };
  5. Return multiple entries to the War Room
    var output = [];
    output.push( { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.error, Contents: 'First part of the script failed.' } );
    output.push( { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: 'Second part of the script completed successfully.' } );
    return output;
  6. Getting time and other metadata for War Room entries
    !js script="e = executeCommand('getEntry', {id: '270@4dfc3b65-9da2-46c5-8751-ebe959f31a7b'}); return e[0].Metadata.Created;"
  7. Getting metadata for War Room entries in JSON
    !js script="e = executeCommand('getEntry', {id: '60@4751'}); return JSON.stringify(e[0].Metadata, null, 2);"
  8. Execute Commands
    var arrResultEntries = executeCommand('ip', { ip: '8.8.8.8' } );
  9. Get Context value
    Fetches the value from the context by it's key. dq(invContext,'key.path')
  10. Set Context
    setContext(args.key, args.value);
  11. Send notifications (e.g. Email)
    var arrResultEntries = executeCommand('send-mail', { to : 'user@domain.com', cc : 'also@domain.com', subject : 'Update on Demisto investigation', body : 'Contents of your message.'  });
  12. Sending an HTTP request or file
    http(url,{Method: method,Headers: headers,Body: body, Username: username,Password: password},params.insecure,params.proxy);
    httpMultipart(url,file_id,{Headers: headers, Username: username,Password: password},body,params.insecure,params.proxy,false,'uploadFile', file_name,true);
    http sends a request and receives a response and httpMultipart sends a file in HTTP protocol
    where:
    URL: the site url (mandatory)
    method is the http method such as 'GET', 'POST', 'PUT' (mandatory)
    fileID is the entry ID of the file in the War room
    headers is the HTTP request headers
    body is the http request body
    username and password are the authentication details if needed
    insecure is a Boolean parameter that is true if secure and false if not secure.
    proxy is a Boolean parameter that is true to use proxy and false if not use proxy.
    file_name is the name of the file that is sent. Can be different than the file ID.;
  13. Handle Errors

    1. if (res[0].Type == entryTypes.error) {

          // Return the error to war room no results to parse.

          return res[0];

      } else {

          var usersOnCall = res[0].Contents;

          var selectedUser = usersOnCall[0];

          if (selectedUser === null) {

      return { ContentsFormat: formats.text, Type: entryTypes.error, Contents: 'error : did not receive any users from PagerDutyGetUsersOnCallNow!' };

          } else {

             return selectedUser.name;

          }

      }var res = executeCommand('PagerDutyGetUsersOnCallNow', { });
  14. Execute Another Script
    You can execute other scripts just as you execute commands, using `executeCommand`.

    var arrResultEntries = executeCommand('IPReputation', { ip: '8.8.8.8' } );

  15. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    setContext('myIPs', ['1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2']);

    setContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  16. Format Results as a table
    In addition to plain text, you can return results to the war room formatted as a table. Error entries can also be formatted as tables, by setting the `entryType` to `error`.

    rows = [ { col1 : 'val1', col2 : 1 } , { col1 : 'val2', col2 : 2 } ]

    return {ContentsFormat: formats.table, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: rows};

  17. Format Results using Markdown

    Results can also be formatted using Markdown.

    var res = '## My title\n### My subsection\n'

    rows = [ { col1 : 'val1', col2 : 1 } , { col1 : 'val2', col2 : 2 } ]

    markdownBasedTable = 'num|col1|col2\n'

    markdownBasedTable += '---|---|---\n'

    for (var i = 0; i < rows.length; i++)

    markdownBasedTable += (i+1) + '|' + rows[i].col1 + '|' + rows[i].col2 + '\n'

    res += markdownBasedTable

    return { ContentsFormat: formats.markdown, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: res } ;
  18. Set Results As Notes

    Results can be set as notes

    var res = '## This is a note\n';

    res += 'It has important information\n';

    return { ContentsFormat: formats.markdown, Type: entryTypes.note, Contents: res, Note: true } ;
  19. Base 64

    btoa: encode string to base 64

    atob: decode base 64 to string

    entrytoa: gets a file entry ID and returns the file in base 64.

  20. Access Investigation Metadata

    When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your script's logic and purpose.

    To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

    return investigation;

    To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

    return incidents;

  21. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: logInfo(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: logDebug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: logError(...)

  22. Close the current investigation
    closeInvestigation({Reason: 'Automated malware playbook completed.'});
  23. Advanced How To
    To be added soon:
    1. Access War Room entries from within a script â€“ return entries matching a specific condition, aggregate content from entries, run a regex-based search against all text in the war room to collect a list of identifiers, and more.
    2. Send files from war room as email attachments.
    3. Access context data directly disregarding arguments.
    4.More tips and use cases to come.
  24. Return a map to the War Room
    return {
    Type: entryTypes.map,
    ContentsFormat: formats.json,
    Contents: {
    lat: <latitude-coordinate>,
    lng: <longitude-coordinate>,
    }
    };
  25. Incident Severity Levels
    • Unknown: 0
    • Informational: 0.5
    • Low: 1
    • Medium: 2
    • High: 3
    • Critical: 4
  26. Incident Statuses
    • Pending: 0
    • Active: 1
    • Done: 2
    • Archive: 3

1. Return result as simple text entry to the War Room
    $demisto.Results("Mission Accomplished")
  2. Return result as a complex entry to the War Room

    Fields

    Field: Type 
    Expected Values: The value is the number that corresponds to the entry type: "1 (note)", "3 (file)", "4 (error)", "7 (image)". There are several additional entry types that Demisto uses internally.
    Description: Specifies the type of entry. Default is "note". 

    Field: Contents
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Raw data of the command or script. If no HumanReadable is provided, this also displays in the War Room.

    Field: ContentsFormat 
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown", "text", "image", "html" 
    Description: Format of the content from the Content field.

    Field: HumanReadable 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Content that displays in the War Room.

    Field: ReadableContentsFormat
    Expected Values: "json", "markdown"
    Description: Format of the content from the HumanReadable field.

    Field: EntryContext 
    Expected Values: N/A 
    Description: Data added to the investigation context (Output Context), which you can use in playbooks.

    Field: Tags 
    Expected Values: List of strings 
    Description: Tags to apply to the War Room entry.

    Example

    entry = {'Type' : entryTypes.note,
    'Contents': data,
    'ContentsFormat' : formats.json,
    'HumanReadable': md,
    'ReadableContentsFormat' : formats.markdown,
    'EntryContext' : context,
    'Tags': @('tag1', 'tag2')}

  3. Return an error to War Room
    myErrorText  = "No matching sensors."
    $demisto.Results( @{ Type = 1; ContentsFormat = "json"; Contents = $contents; EntryContext = $context; ReadableContentsFormat = "markdown"; HumanReadable = $contents } )
  4. Execute Commands
    $arrResultEntries = demisto.ExecuteCommand('ip', @{ip = "8.8.8.8" } )
  5. Set Context
    $demisto.SetContext(demisto.Args().key, demisto.Args().'value')
  6. Set an Incident
    $demisto.ExecuteCommand("setIncident", @{mydate: '2018-02-02T22:58:21+02:00'})
  7. Execute Another Script
    You can execute other scripts just as you execute commands, using `ExecuteCommand`.

    $arrResultEntries = demisto.ExecuteCommand( "IPReputation", @{ ip : "8.8.8.8" } )

  8. Save data in playbook

    Saves data into context for later task scripts within the currently executing playbook.

    $demisto.SetContext('myIPs', '1.1.1.1','2.2.2.2');

    $demisto.SetContext('sender', 'john@acme.com');

  9. Reading file contents
    demisto.ExecuteCommand('getFilePath', @{id: demisto.Args().entryId })
  10. Access Investigation Metadata
    1. When you run a script in a War Room, whether manually or through a playbook, sometimes there is a need to access the investigation metadata, which is accessible through the `investigation` and `incidents` objects which are mapped into the script by the platform. Try the following example in a war room, and in the playground, to see the structure of the object in different investigations. Then you can extract the fields that interest your for your script�s logic and purpose.

     To see the structure of the investigation metadata object:

     $demisto.Results( demisto.Investigation() )

     To see the structure of the incidents metadata object:

     $demisto.Results( demisto.Incidents() )

  11. Printing to Log

    To print to war room: $demisto.Log(...)

    To print to demisto log in INFO: $demisto.Info(...)

    To print to demisto log in DEBUG: $demisto.Debug(...)

    To print to demisto log in ERROR: $demisto.Error(...)

  12. Close the current investigation
    $demisto.ExecuteCommand('closeInvestigation', @{ reason_What-happened : 'Automated malware playbook completed.' } )
